												Note: This game was reviewed with a code provided by the developer this doesn't change my opinion on the game.Dangerous Golf is the game developed by ex developers of Burnout. It provides golf and adds the crash mode from Burnout to provide a fun destruction game, but this falls flat within minutes of you starting playing it.I was looking forward to playing this game and at first I enjoyed my time with it, but the more I played, the more my experience became a pain rather than enjoyment. Dangerous Golf is a simple game. You are thrown into an environment and you are forced to destroy almost everything in sight and then sink in the put. This is pretty simple even later stages. After enough destruction you are given a smashbreaker bar which lights your golf ball on fire and you explode everything you touch. It brings in more strategy in this game, but however this isn't wanted and you just want to cause as much destruction as possible.The events stay regularly the same and there's an event at the end of each tour which is there to test your skills, but it's probably the easiest event out of all of them and the most relaxing as well. Graphically the game looks stunning. The UNREAL 4 engine lighting and destruction look glorious and it's just amazing. One of my favorite features is the game letting you do a flyby of the level and then after you are finished with the level you have a flyby of the level after you destroyed the hell out of it. The game is also quite buggy. The golf ball glitches through walls, smashbreaker balls get stuck in walls and furniture models clipping with each other when you destroy them. The golf ball going through walls happened frequently on my playthrough and I really hope this issue is fixed.The game is also too long for it's own good. There are around 100 courses to go through and all of them are the same, by the time you unlock World Tour 4 you have pretty much seen everything. It get's insanely boring by the end of it. I had to take long breaks after playing for a while cause I was incredibly bored while playing it.The game took me 5 hours to finish everything. There is also a Co Op mode and you can try acing every level, but it's insanely hard, so I doubt it's worth trying to achieve that.The game also has abysmal keyboard and mouse controls so only play if you have a controller cause otherwise there's no point.Overall Dangerous Golf is a rough game, for the price you can get your moneys worth, if you absolutely loved Burnouts Crash Mode, but Burnout had a full game attached to it, but in my opinion this game is kind of boring and only worth getting on sale, but I still suggest skipping it.Pros:+ Amazing Visuals Cons:- Too Boring- Glitches- Keyboard Controls are horrible4/10

												I love Burnout games.  They're some of the best car racing games in my opinion, very arcadey, but when you mess up it turns into beautiful beautiful destruction porn. Dangerous Golf looks to be the same game, in fact I've been tracking this game for awhile, ever since the first beautiful destruction video came out.  The entire world getting destroyed in beautiful slow mo, and I was in love.  I wanted this game.  I bought the humble bundle with this game in to finally get this game, and ... well the love affair is over.   The destruction porn idea is still here in some extent, the problem is it's trying to be burnout without the game behind it.  In dangerous golf you hit your ball into an object filled room to try to destroy as much as you can.  This sounds good.  The downside is the golf game is awful.  I'm a fan of Mario Golf and hot shots golf.  Arcadey golf is acceptable. So that's not the problemThe issue is when you start playing the game, you don't get to see where the ball might go.  Where you aim the ball with the camera does matter, but there's no guideline and you just hit up on the joystick to hit the ball.  Disappointing.  Once you do enough damage (counted in objects, not money) you can go into "Smashbreaker" mode where you bounce around and can do more damage.  There's a set amount of time (or movement), and no bonus time awarded, but you can go around smashing things to your heart's content.     Then you land the ball (you can decide when to stop or when ever you run out of time/momentum).  And you can use a smash shockwave (I forget the name).  Then after all of that, you put the ball into the hole.  Again it seems like it works, but the first time you get to a putting challenge the whole experience falls apart for me.   You realize that putting is a rather shallow point and click experience, point at the whole and put it in.  The puts are so strong, that you can pretty much put anywhere in the general direction and it seems to go in.    The same is true for the tee off.  You basically don't know where the ball will go, because there's no arrow, instead you give it a vague direction and hope it'll smash into enough stuff.  The entire problem of the game is that the player agency is heavily lacking.  The player gets to see amazing destruction, but barely causes the destruction.  There's not even a golf club to hit the ball, the game just fires the ball forward as if out of a cannon.  Granted there's some agency in how the player bounces around the room in a smashbreaker, but overall the experience isn't an orgy of destruction as you'd hope, but the only part of the game that's really interesting.  It's violence and destruction, but rather than being a reward for a particularly good shot, it's the only thing in the game, if you don't get a smashbreaker, you might as well just restart.  "But stuff gets blown up, right?"  Well yeah, that IS what happens.  But the images above are not representative of the game as most of the time, you're so focused on the ball and moving it, the destruction is only there to distract you instead of let you revel in it.   Where every piece of destruction of your car in Burnout Paradise is glorious because you can't do anything but watch, in this game, if you watch you are losing valuable time, and the fact is you camera is so close to the ball you barely can watch anything. The game is built off a scoring system where you can destroy certain objects for a bonus, usually having to destroy between 3-6 at least early on.  And there's a little sparks of interest there.  There's very little strategy to the destruction.  You might hit bucket 1 first instead of bucket 3 but you're still going to hit a ball in a random direction and hope for the best.The thing is everything in this game is trying to be "To the max" this is "EXTREME!" and "Totally awesome".  Everything seems to be trying to be an 11 (the graphics the sound the UI) But this game doesn't earn that. When everything is an 11, everything really is a 5.  If you had three strokes to do a lot of damage and maximize the destruction and if you hit a level THEN you get smashbreaker, they would be a hell of a lot more strategy to this game.  Instead what you get is a single stroke, and then a smashbreaker, and a single putt.  It's a shame because there's a good destruction engine in this game, but that's about all this game is.  There's not an amazing game wrapped around the destruction engine, and from past experience programming games, I have a feeling the destruction engine limited the room size, which is why the game doesn't allow multiple strokes and so on. It's a shame because I LOVED looking at this game and dived in lustfully, but then I hit my head on the bottom of the shallow pool, and chipped a tooth.  Some of the images from the game are glorious, but overall the game doesn't live up to those hopes and dreams of the best parts of Burnout, the destruction.  I might be able to recommend it as part of the humble bundle, but there's no way I could recommend it for even 10 dollars.  A fun diversion, but not much else.

												As with most games, there's the good and the bad, but thankfully not the ugly in this case...The game is quite literally a blast. If I had to compare it to something, I'd say it feels a lot like the old Burnout crash mode. You're thrown into a room and told to wreck ♥♥♥♥.  You generally get a normal swing first, and if you wrack up a decent score, you're given the ability to turn your ball into a bouncing bringer of boom.  Your ball will bounce around, delivering little explosions to anything it touches and further racking up your score.  In some cases you get additional explosions depending on what you hit.  You also have the ability to slow down time to better help you send your destructive little ball where you want it to go.  There is a fair bit of game here, and it keeps things relatively fresh by adding new mechanics and challenges.  I've already clocked 15 hours in it, and the game still feels fairly fresh.  It's a good game to drop into for just a few levels if you just want to kill a half hour or so.As for the bad, I'd have to say it would be the staggering amount of invisible walls within the levels.  This becomes very apparent when given the sticky ball ability.  You'll try to launch your ball through what looks like pure air, only to run into and stick to an invisible object.  Doing this will of course steal one of your limited launches, and ultimately kill your score and hamper your progress.But all in all, it's a rather good dollar to fun ratio.  I grabbed this for all of $1 on humble bundle, but I don't think I would have been terribly disappointed shelling out the full price of $20 for this game.Also, join me in nominating this game for the "I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award" award.
